problem: Let $P(x)$ be a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x - 19,$ the remainder is 99, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x - 99,$ the remainder is 19.  What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x - 19)(x - 99)$?
solution:
By the Remainder Theorem, $P(19) = 99$ and $P(99) = 19.$

When $P(x)$ is divided by $(x - 19)(x - 99),$ the remainder must be of the form $ax + b.$  Thus,
\[P(x) = (x - 19)(x - 99) Q(x) + ax + b,\]for some polynomial $Q(x).$

Setting $x = 19$ and $x = 99,$ we get
\begin{align*}
19a + b &= P(19) = 99, \\
99a + b &= P(99) = 19.
\end{align*}Subtracting the equations, we get $80a = -80,$ so $a = -1.$  Then $-19 + b = 99,$ so $b = 118.$  Hence, the remainder is $\boxed{-x + 118}.$
socratic_questions:
1. Can you explain what the Remainder Theorem is and how it applies to this problem?
2. How can we determine the form of the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x-19)(x-99)$?
3. What can we infer about the degree of the remainder in this case?
4. How can we use the fact that $P(19)=99$ and $P(99)=19$ to solve for the coefficients of the remainder?
5. Can you explain why the coefficient of $x$ in the remainder must be $-1$?
6. How can we use the coefficients we solved for to write the final expression for the remainder?
